segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Maximum lifetime for service ticket security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Maximum lifetime for service ticket security policy setting.

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Maximum lifetime for service ticket security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Maximum lifetime for service ticket security policy setting.

segment.source: The Maximum lifetime for service ticket policy setting determines the maximum number of minutes that a granted session ticket can be used to access a particular service.
segment.target: The Maximum lifetime for service ticket policy setting determines the maximum number of minutes that a granted session ticket can be used to access a particular service.

segment.source: The value must be 10 minutes or greater, and it must be less than or equal to the value of the Maximum lifetime for service ticket policy setting.
segment.target: The value must be 10 minutes or greater, and it must be less than or equal to the value of the Maximum lifetime for service ticket policy setting.

segment.source: The possible values for this Group Policy setting are:
segment.target: The possible values for this Group Policy setting are:

segment.source: A user-defined number of minutes from 10 through 99,999, or 0 (in which case service tickets do not expire).
segment.target: A user-defined number of minutes from 10 through 99,999, or 0 (in which case service tickets do not expire).

segment.source: If a client presents an expired session ticket when it requests a connection to a server, the server returns an error message.
segment.target: If a client presents an expired session ticket when it requests a connection to a server, the server returns an error message.

segment.source: The client must request a new session ticket from the Kerberos V5 KDC.
segment.target: The client must request a new session ticket from the Kerberos V5 KDC.

segment.source: After a connection is authenticated, however, it no longer matters whether the session ticket remains valid.
segment.target: After a connection is authenticated, however, it no longer matters whether the session ticket remains valid.

segment.source: Session tickets are used only to authenticate new connections with servers.
segment.target: Session tickets are used only to authenticate new connections with servers.

segment.source: Ongoing operations are not interrupted if the session ticket that authenticated the connection expires during the connection.
segment.target: Ongoing operations are not interrupted if the session ticket that authenticated the connection expires during the connection.

segment.source: If the value for this policy setting is too high, users might be able to access network resources outside of their logon hours.
segment.target: If the value for this policy setting is too high, users might be able to access network resources outside of their logon hours.

segment.source: In addition, users whose accounts have been disabled might be able to continue accessing network services by using valid service tickets that were issued before their account was disabled.
segment.target: In addition, users whose accounts have been disabled might be able to continue accessing network services by using valid service tickets that were issued before their account was disabled.

segment.source: If the value is set to 0, service tickets never expire.
segment.target: If the value is set to 0, service tickets never expire.

segment.source: It is advisable to set Maximum lifetime for service ticket to 600 minutes.
segment.target: It is advisable to set Maximum lifetime for service ticket to 600 minutes.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsAccount PoliciesKerberos Policy
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsAccount PoliciesKerberos Policy

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features, tools, and guidance to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features, tools, and guidance to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: A restart of the device is not required for this policy setting to be effective.
segment.target: A restart of the device is not required for this policy setting to be effective.

segment.source: This policy setting is configured on the domain controller.
segment.target: This policy setting is configured on the domain controller.

segment.source: Client computers will get the new setting during the next scheduled and successful Group Policy refresh.
segment.target: Client computers will get the new setting during the next scheduled and successful Group Policy refresh.

segment.source: But for domain controllers to assign these new settings immediately, a gpupdate.exe /force is required.
segment.target: But for domain controllers to assign these new settings immediately, a gpupdate.exe /force is required.

segment.source: On the local device, the Security Configuration Engine will refresh this setting in about five minutes.
segment.target: On the local device, the Security Configuration Engine will refresh this setting in about five minutes.

segment.source: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:
segment.target: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:

segment.source: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.
segment.target: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: If you configure the value for the Maximum lifetime for service ticket setting too high, users might be able to access network resources outside of their logon hours.
segment.target: If you configure the value for the Maximum lifetime for service ticket setting too high, users might be able to access network resources outside of their logon hours.

segment.source: Also, users whose accounts were disabled might continue to have access to network services with valid service tickets that were issued before their accounts were disabled.
segment.target: Also, users whose accounts were disabled might continue to have access to network services with valid service tickets that were issued before their accounts were disabled.

segment.source: Configure the Maximum lifetime for service ticket setting to 600 minutes.
segment.target: Configure the Maximum lifetime for service ticket setting to 600 minutes.
